description:
Rhizophagus irregularis is a species of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus (AMF) that forms a symbiotic relationship with the roots of many plant species. It is a member of the phylum Glomeromycota, a group of fungi known for their ability to colonize plant roots and facilitate the uptake of nutrients, particularly phosphorus, from the soil.

The defining characteristics of R. irregularis include its irregularly shaped spores, which can vary in size and morphology, and its ability to form extensive hyphal networks that extend from the plant roots into the surrounding soil. These hyphae act as an extension of the plant's root system, allowing the plant to access a larger volume of soil and increasing its access to essential nutrients and water.

R. irregularis is considered an important component of many terrestrial ecosystems, as it plays a crucial role in the cycling of nutrients and the maintenance of soil health. Its symbiotic relationship with plant roots has been shown to improve plant growth, resistance to pathogens, and tolerance to environmental stresses, making it a subject of significant interest in the fields of agriculture, ecology, and environmental science.
